Award.AwardTitle: A Room-Temperature Portable Terahertz Camera Using Zero Bias Sb-Based Heterostructure Backward Diodes for Imaging Aplications

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
The objective of this research is to explore the performance and realization of compact, potentially low-cost, integrated terahertz (THz)-frequency imaging systems based on heterostructure backward diodes (HBDs) as the detection technology. The approach is to leverage the unique properties of HBDs - record high sensitivity, low noise, and room-temperature operation - integrated with planar antennas for high-performance imaging systems in this frequency range. Integration and interaction of these components will be explored, including detailed design and simulation, development, and experimental demonstration of prototype imaging systems operating in the sub-millimeter-wave through THz regimes. To maximize resolution, a quasi-optical reverse-microscope configuration will be pursued.

The program's intellectual merit centers on the challenges and opportunities afforded by co-integrating these devices for imaging systems. The need for high spatial resolution with a compact footprint dictates novel approaches to imager design; the trade-offs and interactions between component performance, layout, and physical implementation provide an ideal test-bed for evaluating integration concepts. Advances in THz device and integration technology are also expected. Insights gained may also find application in multi-input multi-output (MIMO) systems and other contexts.

The broader impacts include contributions in both education and the creation of new engineering knowledge. The system design concepts will have impact on a range of disciplines; sub-millimeter-wave and THz imaging has applications in medical diagnostics, environmental and hazard sensing, and homeland security. In terms of education, the graduate students will participate in an integrated program of design, development, and prototyping, with exceptional breadth in the important area of integrated system design. Undergraduates will also be involved through summer and honors thesis research.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Submillimeter-wave and terahertz (THz) imaging is a vital concern for many research and technology communities including astronomy, chemistry, biology, medicine, security and defense. However, due to the lack of high performance THz radiation detection devices and other technical challenges, current THz imaging systems either operate only at cryogenic temperatures (e.g., imagers employing superconducting bolometer devices) or require slow mechanical scanning, resulting in bulky and expensive systems. THz detectors employed in room-temperature imagers demonstrated to date generally have exhibited relatively low responsivity and high noise equivalent power (NEP) level (e.g., conventional Schottky-based detectors), leading to limited system dynamic range. In this research, high performance Sb-based heterostructure backward tunneling diodes (Sb-HBDs) have been successfully integrated with planar lens-coupled folded-dipole antenna (FDA) arrays without any additional matching networks for ultrasensitive, real-time, and compact THz focal-plane array (FPA) imaging devices.

For imaging array design, the even-odd mode analysis (EOA) technique has been adopted for calculation of FDA embedding impedances and far-field radiation patterns. An accurate physics-based device model has been developed to describe the behavior of the Sb-HBDs. For circuit fabrication, novel processing technologies have been developed that permit the direct integration of HBDs with planar antennas for quasi-optical FPAs. In addition, a submicron airbridge contact technology for minimizing interconnect parasitics has been introduced for operation beyond 600 GHz (as shown in Fig. 1-3). Finally, testing results both at 200 GHz and 585 GHz have shown promising detection and imaging performance. Research performed in this project is poised to (1) allow very fast room-temperature THz imaging system with high signal-to-noise ratio, high responsivity and dynamic range to be realized, (2) permit low-cost, portable and flexible imaging devices for a wide range of applications, and (3) provide a path for non-scientists to gain cost-effective access to THz imaging systems.

The research supported two Ph.D. students, and five undergraduate students have been involved through summer research programs. Knowledge gleaned from this project has been integrated into the PIs’ graduate and undergraduate courses (e.g., FDA design, tunneling device physics). Research results have led to a number of journal and conference articles, as well as invited talks at international symposiums. In addition to publications, prototype hardware such as compact detectors (see Fig. 4) and FPAs with good performance has been built (for general lab usage and other projects) and characterized. The measurement capabilities developed under this program, which includes an antenna characterization setup, 2D scanning imaging setup and associated software, will be employed in future research.
